title: Arrgh! :)
content:
While working on "Commander Keen 20,000" in Multimedia Fusion 1.5 I developed a method of simulating parallax scrolling that was unique, horribly awkward, annoying to implement, kinda ugly, crude yet highly effective.

I have JUST NOW discovered that the wise folks at ClickTeam created something called the "Background System Box Object" which makes parallax scrolling ridiculously easy.

All that hard work for nothing. This is why I am not a professional programmer. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dopekeen.gif[/img]

title: Re: Arrgh! :)
content:
All I did was:

Step 1. Work in eight-bit color mode.

Step 2. Manipulate the heck out of the palette. Assign four bits to background colours and four bits to foreground colours. Colours 0 thru 15 are the background colours. Colours 16 thru 31 represent the first foreground colour (all sixteen of these colours must have identical RGB values for this to work). Colours 32 thru 47 represent the second foreground colour, and so on. In the most basic permutation of this system, only 31 colours are available per frame: 16 background colours and 15 foreground.

Step 3. Create active background objects and set them to OR mode. That way, backDROP objects show up in front of backGROUND objects. So, say we have a background object of colour 15 (00001111) and a backdrop object of colour 16 (00010000).
15 OR 16 = 31 and since colour 16 is identical to colour 31, the viewer will "see" the backdrop object.

Theoretically this will work in TGF and CNC.
